prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Any documents which demonstrate the actual or potential value of information to the business or to competitors should be maintained for use as evidence. Likewise, any documents which demonstrate that information has been produced as a result of the employer's expenditure of financial or other resources, including effort, time or labour, should be available.[1] Where possible, an employer should be able to demonstrate the independent economic value, both actual and potential, of the information.

Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.), at p. 47; Schauenburg Industries Ltd. v. Borowski (1979), 101 D.L.R. (3d) 701, 25 O.R. (2d) 737 (H.C.J.); Creditel of Canada Ltd. v. Faultless (1977), 81 D.L.R. (3d) 567, 18 O.R. (2d) 95 (H.C.J.); Creditel of Canada Ltd. v. Boothe (1985), 7 C.P.C. (2d) 20, 6 C.P.R. (3d) 507 (Ont. H.C.J.).
